Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of multi-parametric/multimodal spectroscopy (MPMS) apparatus for characterization of functional interfaces

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1337818
Simonian

With increasing interest in functional interfaces, it becomes increasingly important to characterize chemical structures and biomolecules on surfaces in a quantitative fashion, and to test their proper allocation orientation, conformation, activities, stability, etc. This proposal will enhance the power and capabilities of interface characterization sensing techniques by integrating several synergistic surface characterization spectroscopy methods such as surface plasmon,fluorescence, and electrochemical spectroscopies into one new surface analytic system. Although the reasoning for combining all of these techniques is straightforward, currently there is no such instrument available. The main objective of this proposal is to develop a multi-parametric/multimodal spectroscopy (MPMS) system for simultaneous application of surface-mediated optical and electrochemical techniques The proposed MPMS system, which combines three spectroscopic techniques, will facilitate new quantitative insights into the interactions of a broad range of chemical and biological species with rationally designed interfaces. Through the combination of synergistic sensing techniques, this new approach can overcome several key limitations of current, widely-used surface characterization technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A new instrument, designated as the Multi-Parametric/Multi-Modal Spectroscopy (MPMS) device, was designed, built, tested and demonstrated under this project.  This instrument integrates and enables simultaneous measurement of surface plasmon resonance, fluorescence and electrochemical properties to characterize the formation of functional molecular interfaces important in the engineering of new sensors.   The intellectual merit of this project is that these simultaneous measurements will enable scientists to understand the mechanisms and kinetics by which functional molecular interfaces are formed, enabling new high performance sensors to be developed.  Experiments have been completed that demonstrate the instrument can be used to identify: 1) the sequence and kinetics of surface molecular binding events leading to sensor surface construction, 2) the presence of Platelet-Derived Growth Factor (PDGF) that plays an important role in cell division and tumor growth, and 3) the presence of Interferon Gamma that possesses antiviral and immune-regulatory properties.  The experiments that have been conducted demonstrate the broader impact that the instrument may have on human health (detecting and understanding PDGF and Interferon Gamma for treatment of cancers), agriculture and food safety (biosensors to detect bacterial contamination of food), transportation, defense and the environment (new sensors for contaminants produced by internal combustion engines such as mixed oxides of nitrogen, carbon dioxide, carbon monoxide, etc.).
